awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Moving Faculty from Experimentation With to Long-term Adoption of Engaged Student Learning in Analytical Chemistry
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this project is to implement a national professional development program that promotes the use of engaged student learning in the analytical chemistry classroom and laboratory. Each instructor will participate in a two-year process involving a national workshop, regional workshop, and site visit to the individual's campus. An online community will be developed to sustain engagement after the workshops. An education research project will examine the (1) characteristics of professional development workshops and follow-up support activities that result in effective sustained implementation of active learning, (2) ways instructors adapt the materials to suit their teaching philosophies and institutional environments, (3) impact of the implementation of active learning modules on student learning, and (4) best practices for creating an on-line community that supports sustained implementation of active learning. Formative assessment of early workshops will be used to refine and improve the strategies for later workshops and follow-up activities.

This project will promote and study the adoption of evidence-based, active teaching methods by analytical chemical faculty members. Numerous studies show that small-group collaborative learning and inquiry-based activities lead to statistically significant improvements in student learning and increased student retention and engagement, especially among women, underrepresented, and first generation college students. However, wide-spread adoption of active learning pedagogies remains an elusive goal. Intense and collaborative forms of professional development are warranted to bring about changes in teacher knowledge, skills, attitudes, and beliefs that lead to changes in classroom and laboratory instruction. This project's process of networking in person and via an on-line community will provide sustained interaction between participants and facilitators with expertise in active learning leading to a shared vision and substantive change in the teaching methods of participants. The result will be a set of professional development experiences that support sustained adoption of active learning strategies. This will lead to more effective instructors of analytical chemistry courses and enhanced learning on the part of their students.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Teaching practices that actively engage students with content have been shown to improve student outcomes as opposed to more passive practices like traditional lecture or cookbook laboratory experiments. However, such active learning in chemistry courses is still relatively uncommon. The primary goal of this collaborative project was to increase the use of active learning approaches by analytical chemistry instructors in their classrooms and laboratories. This was accomplished by conducting a national professional development program aimed at promoting the use of engaged student learning in the analytical chemistry classroom and laboratory. Project activities included:

  1. Refinement and expansion of intensive multi-day national workshops
  2. Development of follow-up regional workshops
  3. Development of an explicit mentoring process, including site visits
  4. Development of an online community to support instructors
  5. Characterization of the instructional practices of participating instructors

Intellectual Merit: The project involved a series of two-year cycles of faculty development that began with a national workshop where facilitators instructed participants on the nature of active learning, the benefits to students, and modeled examples of active learning in the context of analytical chemistry. The workshops included time for participants to work on developing materials, practice implementing materials, and receive feedback from other participants and facilitators. The participants returned home to put what they learned into practice and the project team used observations and survey data to revise the workshop. The participants attended a follow-up workshop a year later, where they shared their experiences and received additional feedback. The last phase of the program was a site visit where a facilitator observed the participant’s implementation of active learning strategies and provided feedback to the participant. We collected classroom materials every semester in the two-year period and results of the site-visit observations and evaluated the impact of the program on the participants’ instruction. Overall the results were overwhelmingly positive. Survey results indicated participants were very satisfied with the workshops and indicated intentions to incorporate more active learning strategies into their instruction. Site visits indicated that over 90% of the participants were successfully using student-centered instruction. Analysis of materials indicated that while many participants generated materials that were well-scaffolded and included questions that engaged students in analysis or knowledge utilization, a significant number of materials were poorly scaffolded and consisted entirely of lower level questions that focused on memorization or basic comprehension, indicating additional support for activity design is needed.

Broader Impacts: The project resulted in the training of over 80 chemistry instructors in the use of active learning strategies. Most of the faculty involved in this project have incorporated the strategies they learned about into their larger introductory courses in addition to courses focused on analytical chemistry. The resulting classroom implementation has impacted thousands of students across the country in a wide variety of institutions ranging from community colleges to small liberal arts colleges to large research universities. Work from the project has resulted in the creation of a “Shorter Activities” section on the Active Learning site on the Analytical Sciences Digital Library (ASDL) as a repository for activities developed by participants in our project.  These materials are not as fully developed as those already on the site (e.g., they do not have instructor’s manuals), but they are still useful exercises for other individuals interested in active learning to consider for use in their courses.  Materials are considered for this site twice a year and undergo peer-review before inclusion on the site. To date, 162 items have been added to the Shorter Activities section of the ASDL website. All materials on the site are under the Creative Commons Copyright and freely available for others to use. In addition to a symposium at a national American Chemical Society meeting, the work of the project has resulted in a symposium series book highlighting Active Learning in Analytical Chemistry. Authors include members of project leadership team, facilitators, and faculty participants. The updates to the ASDL and the symposium series book will continue to serve as resources for chemistry instructors to support further adoption of active learning in the chemistry curriculum.

 


Last Modified: 12/30/2021
Modified by: Renee S Cole
